Experience RET Design Engineer Intel Corporation September 2013  – Present (2 years) Hillsboro, OR Research Assistant University of Wisconsin-Madison September 2007  –  August 2013  (6 years) Madison, WI My research in the group of Juan de Pablo employs coarse-grain molecular models, in concert with advanced sampling methods, to probe questions in the realm of biophysics. My focus is on biological methods for confining DNA. As a semi-flexible polyelectrolyte, DNA can be difficult to compact and yet, in every organism and virus, volume compaction of up to three orders of magnitude are common. We study two representative systems. In the case of dsDNA bacteriophage (viruses that infect bacteria), a protein motor actively packages the DNA and provides the work required for compaction. In the case of eukaryotes, DNA is packaged with the help of a protein building blocks. These proteins, histones, when complexed with DNA, create nucleosomes. The organization of nucleosomes in the genome has important consequences and we can use our computational tools to study the behavior of these building blocks for genome compaction. Intern Westinghouse Electric Company May 2006  –  August 2007  (1 year 4 months) I worked with an international team of scientists and engineers to bring high temperature gas reactor technology into the U.S. as part of the Next Generation Power Plant project. This work included performing statistical analyses on fuel failure data to improve reactor safety models and interfacing with international partners to prepare DOE grant applications. Coop/Intern Albany International May 2005  –  December 2005  (8 months) I used finite element analysis techniques to identify stable geometries for next generation forming fabrics. Coop/Intern MIT Lincoln Laboratory August 2004  –  April 2005  (9 months) I worked with a multi-disciplinary team to design housing equipment for optical components of a space vehicle. I performed finite element analyses on proposed designs and worked with the designers to ensure that the final product could withstand the stresses and vibrations anticipated during deployment and operation while falling within mass and size constraints. Coop/Intern Center for Advanced Microgravity Materials Processing, Northeastern University June 2003  –  August 2004  (1 year 3 months) Boston, MA I completed two projects in the lab of Prof. Al Sacco Jr. while at Northeastern University. My first project (completed during a co-op assignment) saw me design and implement a protocol for monitoring VOC concentration in a biosensor testing environment. I used Gas Chromotography and Mass Spec to quantify analyte concentrations. My second project, completed during a subsequent independent study, employed molecular modeling to elucidate a mechanism for racemate separation in a modified zeolite device. My focus is on biological methods for confining DNA. As a semi-flexible polyelectrolyte, DNA can be difficult to compact and yet, in every organism and virus, volume compaction of up to three orders of magnitude are common. We study two representative systems. In the case of dsDNA bacteriophage (viruses that infect bacteria), a protein motor actively packages the DNA and provides the work required for compaction. In the case of eukaryotes, DNA is packaged with the help of a protein building blocks. These proteins, histones, when complexed with DNA, create nucleosomes. The organization of nucleosomes in the genome has important consequences and we can use our computational tools to study the behavior of these building blocks for genome compaction. Summary I am a computational scientist with ~10 years of experience in massively-parallel physical simulations in the area of computational fluid dynamics, combustion, photo-lithography, and finite-element analysis.  
 
I work in the intersection of engineering physics, high performance computing, and applied mathematics. In particular, have expertise in the following areas: 
 
1. Physics: Reacting flows, chemical kinetics, turbulent flows, computational lithography, and finite element analysis. 
 
2. Computing: Parallel programming, HPC, MPI, OpenMP, OpenCL, CUDA, Many-core, GPGPU, Vectorization, C++, Fortran, Performance optimization, MATLAB, Simics - for pre-silicon studies. 
 
3. Applied Mathematics: Numerical linear algebra, Direct & Iterative linear solvers, Numerical solution to Partial Differential Equations (PDEs), Image processing.
